description: This course is intended as a general introduction to political theory since 1900, examining prominent theorists of politics including Max Weber, Hannah Arendt, Carl Schmitt, Isaiah Berlin, Jurgen Habermas, John Rawls, Michel Foucault, and Jacques Derrida. Our theme for the Fall 2012 course will be: The Disenchantment of the World? Topics include: the nature of the the political and the concern, particular to the last century, that politics is itself under attack; the spread of liberal democracy across the globe and a critical appraisal of the moral meaning of this regime; contemporary theories of social justice; and an exploration of various issues pertaining to violence and the politics of security.
name: CONTEMPORARY POL.THOUGHT

values.comments: This course examines the major influences and contributions to political thought from 1900 to the present. This course discusses the nature of politics, appraises liberal democracy, and explores the problem of emergency powers. Students will study works from authors such as Weber, Arendt, Dewey, Berlin, Habermas, Rawls, Foucault, and Derrida.  Students praised the course content while warning that the material can be challenging. Students agreed that, “the readings are very complex.” Even though the course includes works by, “complex political philosophers,” students found that each was thoroughly explained and analyzed. Some students cautioned, however that, “the amount of reading was difficult to keep up with.”  Professor Green received overwhelmingly positive feedback from students. One student described Professor Green as, “a brilliant man who brings passionate intensity to his course material.” Students were impressed with how willing Professor Green was to remain after class to field questions and clarifications. Students were likewise appreciative that Professor Green provided lecture notes before classes as an aid.  Students in this course recommended that future students have an interest in political philosophy if they wish to gain the most from this course. The course is open to both college freshmen and upperclassmen.
